In Spanish we say verde-estribor-derecha, rojo-babor-izquierda = green-starboard-right, red-port-left. The play is in all the Es (pronounced eh), particularly in the first syllable, in verde, estribor and derecha, and the Os (oh) in rojo and babor, and izquierda just follows. That identifies the side and the light on that same side.

ok this was a nice video for the amazing US Coast Guard, however, in WW2, a team of mathematicians needed to give our boats some types of search patters way before these new AI type of systems. There were 9 different variables in how to most effectively search for someone.
This analysis could still be used today, for someone hiking or at sea if you did not have any assistance. The most CRITICAL variable out of all the variables was, THE distance between the two people searching where they could confirm that the subject was not there… I cannot find the equation. So, if you need to find someone or something. Spread-out as far as you can in some pattern, where u can see the most distanced between each of you…….. This was more beneficial than faster speed searching and the other variables that I can’t remember 😊

Looks easy enough, right? Now, try to imagine doing those search patterns and spotting that bobbing head in current conditions off Newport Oregon: Wind south, 10-15 kts gusting to 25 kts (i.e. sustained windspeed 11-17 mph with gusts of 28 mph), wind waves South 3 ft at 4 seconds (i.e. waves are three feet in height, with crests four seconds apart, meaning that for a relatively significant portion of every four seconds, a bobbing object one foot in height will likely be hidden from an observer near sea level) and a westward swell at 3 feet and 9 seconds (Meaning, you've got the wind throwing waves in one direction and ocean currents throwing waves in another). Waves will be breaking with frequent "white horses" (the white bubbles and foam on the crest of a breaking wave), and there will likely be rain, with heavily overcast skies. The air temperature is a balmy 52 degrees Fahrenheit in the City of Newport without the windchill, and the water temperature at the tidal station in Garibaldi Oregon is an even balmier 50.9 degrees Fahrenheit. Also, this is for open water; near shore, around offshore rocks and reefs, and especially around river bars, those conditions are going to be even more exciting.

It can actually be really hard to spot things in the water. Once when I was out sailing I accidentally dropped an orange ziplock bag with dried mangoes overboard, since it was locked and would presumably float, I figured I would turn around to pick it up again, but I couldn't see it anywhere. I zigzagged the area quite a few times, until I gave up, but as I was sailing away I finally spotted it and picked it up. This was on a sunny relatively calm day, and the bag was quite visible once I was on top of it, but it taught me how hard it can be to spot something or someone in the water. Just taking my eyes of it for a moment to adjust the sails and turn the boat around, was enough to completely loose it.

If you ever are unlucky enough to loose someone overboard, try to assign one person onboard to constantly look at where the person in the water is, not taking their eyes of them for a second.

4:20 -- RE: Why Triangles for Sector Search; FYI, this doesn't only apply to "on the water" but to all aircraft, and presumably spacecraft as well. If you examine the triangles, you'll notice that they're EQUILATERAL, with 60 degrees being the "magic angle" that solves the practical problem. It is also possible to conduct searches with angles other than 60 degrees and getting similar results. 72 degrees x 5 turns, for example, will also give a 360 degree coverage, the same as 60 degrees x 6 turns.

I'm a public policy guy—I figure out how to solve problems, analogous to whoever came up with all this but different skills—and it's interesting that when you look at these people, they're highly-skilled engineers.  Like someone figured out what method they're going to use to maximize their likelihood of finding someone, but you don't just hand that off with some software to a few McDonalds fry cooks and tell them to follow the directions; the people on the boat are the same kinds of engineers that actually came up with all of this methodology.  We often think of these folks on the front line as hired grunts who just operate the equipment, but in reality they need to be able to solve complex problems in real time on their own.  They need to understand the math, the physics, the theory behind all of this.  Awesome to see this stuff close up so we can see who they really are.

Datums are relaive to that which is around it.   If the body of water moves, and the marker moves with the current, the datum is essentially zero in the body of water.   In this case, since the datum mimics a person in the water, the datum is theoretically remaining true to the person in the water.   Therefore, it creates a perfect reference point to center the VS search (ie, the datum)

That little “floaty thing that’s just a blinking light” is an EPIRB…….An Emergency Position Indicating Radio Beacon or EPIRB is used to alert search and rescue services in the event of an emergency. It does this by transmitting a coded message via the free to use, multinational Cospas Sarsat network. A 406 MHz distress frequency signal is sent via satellite and earth stations to the nearest rescue co-ordination centre. EPIRBs also transmit a homing signal via 121.5 MHz to help rescue services to pinpoint the beacons location. Jesus dude. Why would you say stuff you do not absolutely know??? Blows my mind. They didn't mention in regard to the other search patterns, that a parallel search goes with the direction of drift (parallel), and a creeping line search goes perpendicular to and against the direction of drift, starting at the furthest downwind point. There are a lot of variables regarding floating objects and how they behave, whether they are affected more by wind (a light boat with a high profile) or more by current (a person low in the water). A sector search once "saved my life" when I lost my wedding ring in the ocean at a beach on my honeymoon. In reference to your point about Coasties being able to spot things in the water:
Whilst training for my pilot’s licence, to start with, I found it difficult to spot airfields at a distance. As I gained experience, I developed a skill - a skill that enabled me to spot airfields from a distance. Whenever I take up a passenger, I play a game with them - I ask them if they can spot a nearby airfield. I tell them that they will be surprised when they realise where it is and they will be confused as to why they did not spot it until they were almost right on top of it. I’m watching aircraft taxiing around and taking off or landing on the runway and they are still struggling to actually see the airfield… and when they finally spot it… Yep, they’re blown away that they did not see it earlier.
I think that much the same thing is happening here. When you KNOW what it is that you should be seeing, it’s easier to prime your attention such that you will quickly spot your target.
… and I have plenty of video evidence of this in action, not just in terms of tiny, airfields, but also in respect of international airports.

If you like nomographs, have you ever used an E6-B and the wind correction wheel they use in flying? In a way, the victor sierra is similar to a class of maneuvers in flying called "ground reference maneuvers". Imagine trying to fly in a circle over a point on the ground with the wind blowing. If you don't compensate for the fact the the whole mass of air is moving, you'll end up flying a path along the ground that looks like a stretched-out spring. You have to fly the opposite path relative to the air so the sum of the two is a stationary circle.

Fun Fact: The right side of the ship is called "starboard" because on old ships the rudder was not at the end of the ship and centered but on the right side. "star" is derived from "steering". With the rudder on the right you would land with the quay to the left, hence the name "port side".

Fun Fact 2: This old way of steering a ship is still used, even in aviation. The pilot is sitting on the right side (starboard). An you enter and leave an airplane always on the left side (port side).

At minute 24:24 the BM2 Weston references SINS packages, the subtitles translated it as sense packages. SINS stands for "Scalable Integrated Navigation System." Weston was talking about the roll out of the new "SINS II" that upgraded Coast Guard assets from the older NMEA 0183 standard to the newer NMEA 2k and also providing more capabilities. These systems include components such as: GPS, Depth, weather sensors, RADAR, repeater displays and the Raymarine MFD (multi-function display) that they were charting the search pattern on the RBM.

I am an ex-Coastie and have personally saved many lives, working SAR on the west coast of Florida.

VERY satisfying work, by the way, which CENTERS around one thing:

EVERY U S Coastie is on the same page.

We were all trained to focus on one thing- saving human lives.

I once was on the bow as we rounded a buoy at night when I saw a red flare. I stood pointing at it. My coxain (boat driver) KNEW EXACTLY what that meant and immediately adjusted our vector (speed & direction).

Long story short: A US Navy Tomcat had flamed out and the pilot ejected his co-pilot.

The ejection chair automatically set a red illumination flare. I saw it.

We saved the pilot's life. He almost drowned anyway - rough seas.

Practice and EXQUISIT TRAINING is key.

Thank you Charlie Gulf.

I was having SCUBA diving lessons with my father and my sister once and in the same boat there was another group who were taking underwater and surface rescue lessons, so there was a "code word" for anyone who wanted to be "rescued" by them that was "PIZZA".
So if you were in the water, you could cry "pizza" and they had to act as if you were crying for help.
(The use of the code word was so in the case another boat appeared, they wouldn't confuse a fake cry for help with a real one, because if we actually needed help, we would cry for help normally and in this case, whoever is closer should help)
It was fun.

An at the end of the day, when we were going back to the dock, everyone already changed clothes, I saw their instructor sitting in the back of the boat with his wife at his side, he gave his glasses to his wife, and he felt from the boat crying "PIZZA".
Half of the trainees had that face "you're an a******“, but one of them was impressive, in less than a second after the cry he was already jumping (thinking of it now, maybe he also saw the instructor preparing before it happened and was ready for it).

You can remember starboard as the right side of the boat by a real reason instead of word tricks that you might mess up: westward sailing ships from Europe would find Polaris(i.e., the “star”) on their right.
When returning to Europe, i.e, “port”, Polaris would be on their left.
If you want to use the word “post” as a mnemonic, port wine is red, and the port light is red.

Good video, it brings back lots of memories. We used to run our own cases and search patterns, that was before this "Sector" thing came about. Our AOR had 26 foot tides, 9-12 kt currents, whirlpool and reversing waterfalls to deal with. Yes, trying to find a person or even a small vessel in the water, debris etc is hard, especially in fog, after dark or in rough weather.

Standardization is key. Any boat crew can operate together at any time, anywhere. People who've never met each other can run a boat. On standard boats everything is identical. That's imperative when a disaster or something happens and people from all over get pulled into one area. We did it on 9/11 and a year later. Personnel came from all over to NYC and were able to run 41's and work together as if we always had.

comment_text: The software they're using was developed by just one employee many years ago! He was actually asked to stay on for years after his retirement because he was the only person who knew how to work the software! I believe that the search pattern originally included eight search objects (it was hard to get people to agree to just go adrift for research!) but eventually expanded to the number that we have today. The setup became so well used because it was considerably more effective than traditional search patterns (although never perfect). Sadly I heard all of this years ago so I can't remember if this was the story of SAROPS (the current system) or SARPS (the original system). On one hand it was the first of it's kind so surely it was SARPS, but on the other I remember it's use continuing until fairly recently, which might make it SAROPS (which started being used in 2003).

Finally I see two potential task for the future 1.) join forces between the coast guard and IT companies and figure out if collection GPS signal data from mobile phones on boat could be used compute near shore ocean current patterns (Google for sure knows how to implement something like this and I bet they would be very happy if they could help). It is apparently from the very old days of holding a long paddle off the side of the boat to steer.
That "steering board" would be on the right side, since most people are right handed.
Boats would dock on the other side (left) so they didn't smash the steering board against the dock.

Anyways, once something actually makes sense, it tends to be much easier to remember ;)

The software they're using was developed by just one employee many years ago! He was actually asked to stay on for years after his retirement because he was the only person who knew how to work the software! I believe that the search pattern originally included eight search objects (it was hard to get people to agree to just go adrift for research!) but eventually expanded to the number that we have today. The setup became so well used because it was considerably more effective than traditional search patterns (although never perfect). Sadly I heard all of this years ago so I can't remember if this was the story of SAROPS (the current system) or SARPS (the original system). On one hand it was the first of it's kind so surely it was SARPS, but on the other I remember it's use continuing until fairly recently, which might make it SAROPS (which started being used in 2003).

comment_by: John B Hall MSN, APRN, Aviator, Investigator
comment_text:
Another point to add on search patterns... there is some thing called track line spacing; the search target dictates the track line spacing. For example, if the search target is a person in the water, the standard track line spacing is 0.1 nm. (Helo standard spacing on the 0.1 nm spacing, different search platforms may have different track line spacing) A small kayak, might have a track line spacing of 0.25. These are typically applied towards the CS and PS search patterns. However, this is also put into consideration on a VS search as well... and the track spacing is effectively the same a the leg length used in the VS search pattern.

Also, the helicopters and fixed wing aircraft have radio equippeed data marker bouys; when arriving on scene one of the first tasks is drop a DMB and one of last is to relocate the DMB and then pass that data back to the RCC (Rescue Coord Center). This is then used to determine the set and drift; which then is used to adjust the search plan as each phase of the search progresses.

One really important point for those who head out on the water and want the best chance of being found... DO NOT RELY ON A CELL PHONE!!!!! Take a hand held radio, ALL CG assetts are equipped to monitor and DIRECTION FIND on marine band radios (and even othe readio frequencies) most CG assetts CAN NOT DIRECTION FIND on a cell phone signal. This can drastically increase your chances of being found... even a cheap BAO FENG radio can be programmed with VHF frequencies and would allow person in distress to be found quickly. That radio costs about $40.

As a point of reference, a human head is about the size of a basket ball... so place that in the water and try to find it from 600 feet away... it is really tough.

A few other safety tips...
File a float plan, have life jackets and make sure the jackets have retro-reflective tape - at night it can really increase your chances of detection in the water. Signal flares and mirrors also work. Consider taking a safe boating course via the USCG.

Keep in mind, safe trips on the water do not happen by accident... they happen by careful and discrete planning that is done well before you cast the lines off the boat. (I will also add this applies to those who fly small general aviation aircraft over the water!)

Most SAR cases are rooted in a 'failure of imagination', the victims off failed to imagine that things could go wrong.

Getting smarter every day will help you be safer every day too...

I realize these guys do great work most of the time but I also remember my own lost at sea experience off the Florida keys 25 years ago. About two hours before sundown five miles out, I twisted the bushing out of my I/O propeller returning to the marina.  I switched to my small outboard motor to hobble in from a snorkeling trip.  A thunderstorm between me and shore suddenly developed within minutes with high winds and six foot waves which started pushing my small fly-bridge cruiser out into the Gulf through a series of shallow reefs.  My outboard didn't have enough power to even turn into the wind and the huge waves were washing over the outboard most of the time as we were pushed sideways by the wind so I shut it down before it sucked in sea water. The sky turned black as the sun went down.  We could no longer see the reefs in the dark.  The lightning was right on top of my boat and things were getting desperate.  My wife called the Coast Guard about our situation with children on board.  Their only question was if we were sinking.  We said no, not yet.  They refused to come out and told us to throw the anchor and they would call a commercial tow company. The anchor hit the bottom but would not hook up as we were blown miles in the dark. When the anchor did finally hook up it rolled my boat on its side as it pulled the anchor line tight.  Luckily everyone was down below or we would have been thrown out of the boat. The commercial tow company radioed that they would not come out because of the severity of the storm affected their GPS.  In those days I could only afford a Loran and charts to navigate which wasn't accurate enough in the dark with the reefs surrounding us.  After about half an hour of pounding in large waves and lightning with thunder right on top of us, the storm ended.  The commercial tow finally arrived.  Had our boat hit the surrounding jagged reefs in the dark it would have been a tragic ending.  At the time I didn't think that even the Coast Guard could have arrived in time but I still have bitter feelings that they refused to try.

Nice video. Back in the 70's when I was a Coast Guard Helo pilot there were no computers, GPS, calculators, or autopilots. We did expanding squares, parrallel lines, track lines, and creeping patterns. We calculated it manually on out knee pads with a Jeppsen flight computer. What we did have, if we had an approximate position, was a datum marker buoy. It was a radio transmitter with a flashing light that we dropped. It drifted with the current and it made it easier particularly for expanding square patterns as your turn points were specific radio directional headings to the datum. Of course we also had to compensate for the wind which was different from the current since the aircraft was affected by the wind and the wind over the body of water was different from at base so our heading on each leg had to be offset. Things are a lot more complicated. A body is mainly carried by the current but a boat or raft is also affected by the wind from the amount of surface area above the water. Then, is there a sea drogue deployed or not which would give a compromise between wind and water. The wind is constantly changing so how long has it been since the event and how long is the search taking. A storm system going through changes wind direction as it passes. There is fetch which is surface current from long term wind versus ocean current such as the Gulf Stream. They may actually be going in the opposite direction. Waves, though they mainly are going up and down also effects drift by causing slippage for a boat or raft. Things are a lot easier now for the pilots with onboard computers and autopilots that will fly the search pattern allowing the pilots and crew to spend more time looking outside for that tiny dot of a head or life jacket in rough seas. I actually got to do the prototype testing on the first aircraft flir systems which really helps out. Destin, are you sure you really want to get into this deep stuff? Enjoy all the math. I look forward to seeing the rest of the series.

Fun fact about a moving datum. Some nautical GPS systems will automatically calculate the direction and speed of drift from the steering input needed to keep a boat on a desired course.   With this they can create and track a moving waypoint.   This can be used to track an object drifting in the water.  If a boat has this capability, there is sometimes a "man overboard" button on the GPS that allows the crew to instantly create a moving waypoint.  This makes finding someone who fell off a fast moving boat much easier.

'datum' is the singular form of 'data'

also, the other search patterns also have names based on elements of the search specifics

Search patterns are designated by letters. The first letter indicates

the general pattern group:

T = Trackline
P = Parallel
C = Creeping Line
V = Sector
S = Square

The second letter indicates the number of SRU’s assigned to that
pattern:

S = Single Unit
M = Multi-unit

The third letter indicates specialized patterns or instructions; the two
most commonly used are:

R = Return
N = Non-return

In training for my commercial license, I took a Fast Rescue Boat (FRB) certification course and this was nearly the exact same to the industry standard. Coasties aren't always the first on scene, and when that happens it's up to civilian mariners to respond. I had the pleasure of learning 90% of this info over the course of 5 days and this video is spot on. Well done⚓

Something else to keep in mind, civilian ships that may respond may have a greater height of eye which aids in the search as opposed to the 10 feet you might get on the boat featured in the video. And typically these vessels are equipped with FRBs for more maneuverability and smaller freeboard for recovery:)

Destin - I do notice that in your garage you have used PVC for your shop air piping - That my friend, is a no no. It's DANGEROUS. Over time, PVC degrades and becomes brittle, and then if it ruptures, it sends sharp shards of plastic shooting through the air that can seriously injure someone. You should use either copper pipe, black gas pipe, or aluminum core polymer piping like Rapid Air. The last option is awesome. Love your videos. Have a peaceful day!

This video brings back lot of old memories!!!I was a Coastie sonar tech MANY, MANY years ago and we ran search patterns hunting for subs. The techniques we used are somewhat similar to these here except the subs tried very hard to avoid us. We used the 3 minute rule constantly during the search and when we made contact..... Distance (yds) traveled divided by 100= speed in kts and we did in all in our heads in real time. For example if the target moves 300 yards in 3 minutes they are doing 3 kts. I loved trying to keep up with sub skippers. It seems youse guys use decimal nautical miles in your searches nowdays, we used yards making it easier for to use the 3 minute rule, plus it gave us faster updates on target cse and speed. I am somewhat jealous of the Guard nowdays because you have the computer with the software to do your plotting. We plotted targets manually on a device called a DRT (Dead Reckoning Tracer) and did a lot of target motion analysis  in our heads, underwater fire control solutions to shoot homing torpedoes we calculated manually.

What is interesting about this is about the individual who developed this science. I do not recall his name..

This is the short story of this individual.

He worked for DOD as an oceanographer expert .
In the 60's during the Johnson administration a B 52 while refueling over the Atlantic west of Spain crash, with a nuclear bomb.

He developed the equation for the set and drift. The equation was so complicated because he had account for the set and drift of the bomb falling from a high altitude and the set and drift of the bomb when it hit the water.

The equation was so complex that he had to hire a team of mathematicians. To develop the serch pattern.

A few years later the USS Sorpeian sank. He refined his equation for other variables. When the submarine was found. The navy took him seriously and refind his work and this is what you showed.

The movie men of honor scene about where the bomb was recovered was the crash of the B 52

There is a book out there that details his story.

A different way to remember which side is Port or Starboard side: Port side and Starboard side are in Portuguese Bombordo and Estibordo. Bombordo contais the word 'bom' (meaning good). There is a reason why one side is 'good'. It was the name portuguese sailors gave to the land side (Africa in this case) when navigating to India. The land side Its 'good' in the sense it is safe (and they can always count on it for reference and refuge) So if you go around Africa from Europe to India, Bombordo (also Port side, the side where ports are) is the left. I never again forgot which side is which based on the source of the word and the context where it was created

comment_text: This patterns reminded me of patterns for farming operations. Every pattern is good for certain conditions. For example, the most efficient way for harvest is "narrowing square" or "narrowing parralel" but if there are wild animals spotted in the area, you need "expanding parralel" pattern for those animals/birds to be able to escape.

BTW, regarding your method for remembering port and starboard, my understanding is, starboard comes from steering board. Think of those ancient ships, or even a Viking ship, with the big flat board hanging off the right side of the stern (they didn't have a flat section like we do today where we attach a rudder). It was a steering board. It usually had a perpendicular handle that you pushed back and forth to twist it. Yeah a side rudder, on the right side, since most of us are right-handed. So, the steering side, with a steering board is starboard. --Scoutmaster Nebeker
As a person who lives in Rochester, NY  it's so interesting to see how they work different bodies of water. (P.s. did you get a garbage plate?)

As a (much less experienced) mechanical engineer as well, I think it makes perfect sense to call the buoy a datum because it is stationary RELATIVE to the drift of the water. You are keeping track of your starting point relative to the drift, not geological coordinates like the GPS uses, and thus measuring the exact drift at the same time!

Nice vid- I used to work on nav s/w for airborne SAR with a variety of search patterns, drift parameters and so on.

By the way, quibble time: Saying "GPS coordinates of an RBM ..." is just 'wrong'. They are the coordinates of the boat. How they're determined is another matter (GPS, LORAN-C, INS, VLF/Omega astrogation, ...). Indeed, GPS' coordinate system is actually cartesian (3D) earth centered/earth fixed (XYZ with the origin at the WGS84 centre of the earth and rotates with the planet) ... so when the "GPS" determines your location, the navigation system has to convert that to L/L (or other coordinate system). And yes most "GPS" devices do all that, and the navigating, mapping, recording, displaying etc. ... so people have lazily been calling them "GPS coordinates".

[yes, I know LORAN-C and Omega are discontinued...]

The reason that the old time seafarers picked 360 degrees for the circle is that it supports the rule of 9s, and great circle routes ( the artillery folks opted for 6400 mils in a circle because shooting required more accuracy). To start the lesson.     Cardinal points add up to 9, Never Eat Sour Worms, in a clockwise direction——opposite directions add up to each other, units stay the same however  10s and 100s are added. 3 & 6 are between the cardinal numbers. 7:20 … When I was a kid in Brazil, whistling was one of the very first things I learned with my friends.
The difference the way we do is straight up your index and middle fingers, holding your ring finger with your thumb and doesn’t matter the way your little finger is positioned, the rest is the same, folding your tongue with the two straight fingers, just make sure use ONLY the tip of your 2 fingers while folding your tongue, and blowing it up. This way you can make the sound actually even a higher pitch than the sound you both made on this video. Until this day (I am 61 Y/O) I use this method to get the attention of anyone or for anything.

But I am an ex-Coastie and really appreciated the state of the art that has changed. Great new gear and the level of professionalism has grown by leaps and bounds. When I was on board ship (a CG Cutter back in the day) I stood lookout on many searches. We didn't have GPS back then, so did almost all our searches by compass.
Fast forward to today, and I participate in searches with the Civil Air Patrol. We do sector searches in airplanes, so this search model is very familiar to me. But instead of drift, we have to deal with wind speed at altitude, since the wind will blow you off course. That is compensated by crabbing into the wind and applying more or less power, depending on upwind or downwind legs of the search.
One thing that confused me with this Coastie search was that the guy timing downstream and upstream legs said it took "x" seconds to do each leg, and he was using the same amount of time for up or down stream. So, I assume that the boatswain mate reduced throttle down current and increased it up current in order to compensate for the current, right?
Anyway, you should do a similar comparison for a CAP sector search. I think your audience would really appreciate seeing the similarities and differences. Thanks!

As a random lateral connection.  I have seen many pro paragliders recommending this search pattern for thermals.  Most guides say to turn into the thermal.  But in doing so you often just circle past it and miss it.  The solution, apparently is to do a 270* turn away from where you think the thermal is, which should then align you to pass through the centre of it.  It also accounts for your wind drift and the thermals.

Really cool video.  In college I was in a SAR group in St. Petersburg Fl.  Ive conducted searches with assets from Sector St. Pete.  That search grid where you ID the VS search pattern was very familiar.  For an urgent search, like a person in the water at night, we would run a multi vessel parallel search with their RBM and our SAR vessels, and the helo would run the VS using their FLIR at the same time after dropping off a datum.  The movement of the datum we would use to modify search parameters through the search.  Water searches, often at night are extremely difficult, but with this type of overlapping coverage, using real time data, we had pretty good success.

Really great to take a look a boat search procedures. I've only done underwater search and recovery (well usually it's rescue also :-) Generally use a square pattern or bottom contour using depth to control drift. In low visibility for short distance stuff a line and reel is handy and spacing according to visibility. Since we rarely dive alone, we can space out divers at the limits of visibility to cover a larger swath. The Victor Sierra would be just as useful in a dive scenario where current plays a major role. 9 one minute legs with 60 degree turns at the outsides is feasible but it again depends on visibility. A boat might also have to shorten that pattern in fog or something.

if you go to the nordic origins, its not starboard but styrbord , and it means the side where the steering board on boats was traditionally mounted on the right side, so it's always the right side of the normal forward direction of the vessel you are on

Now, in nautical speak, you have port and starboard for each side. You also have marker lights red and green, to indicate to a nearby vessel which side of of your vessel is facing them at night, thereby indicating which direction you are travelling for collision avoidance. As a boy, I figured out these similarities to get them straight in my head. Red is a shorter word than green, port is a shorter word than starboard, and left is a shorter word right. Thus left is port, signified by a red light, while right is starboard, signified by a green light! Simple!

One of the searches our vessel located the debri and sunken vessel of the lost fisherman, such an odd feeling of joy mixed with sorrow. Both men were eventually located, unfortunately neither alive. We located their debri and vessel along the southwest side of Gaillard Island in the northern half of Mobile Bay, one man was found near the Heron Bay cutoff and the other was found on Petit Bois Island in Mississippi. One thing you learn - or certainly should at any rate - when you're learning to sail is about set and drift...."Set is referred to as the current's direction, expressed in true degrees. Drift is referred to as the current's speed, which is usually measured in knots. ... The vessel's speed through the water is referred to as the speed over the ground and the current can affect how fast or slow the vessel moves through the water." This is really important on large lakes or oceans where you can otherwise easily get lost. It's also crucial in determining where someone may be in SAR operations if they've gone into the drink. All boaters should learn about these things.

Destin, It is very important to understand that the First leg of a "VS" or "Vector/Single Unit" Search pattern is with the set (Direction). This statement is also true for the "SS" or "Square/Single Unit" Search Pattern. Only other thing  to add is the 1 minute legs or 6kts for 1 minute = .1NM Track spacing. This track spacing changes depending on the weather and object,  but for short its always .1NM for a PIW (Person In Water) but could be .2, .5, or even 1.0NM for small to large vessels. These do normally apply with the Parallel, Creeping and Trackline but could be applied to drifting patterns.  As stated in the video Sector's normally send those but if they cant or don't in time we could compute the same patterns if we know the object and add in the "On Scene" Weather. Lastly we often times start with a Parallel then find a life jacket or debris and then switch to a Vector.  Awesome video though, thank you for putting the Coast Guard in the spot light.

Starboard comes from steering board. In olden times the steering board was at the right rear of the boat so the seaman could use his right hand to steer. Thus, the right side of the boat was the steering board side, or more simply starboard.

Because the steering board was hanging over the right side boats would dock with the left side against the dock, so the left side was known as the port side, or simply port.

I'm a little confused by the VS visualization, seeing as you never actually go in the direction you THINK you'll be going while on a boat. There seems to be an assumption that while the target drifts, the boat does not, and that's not how boats work. You can point your boat at true north, push ahead for a minute at 5 knots, and, surprise, you'll end up going towards 30deg because there's a strong east current pushing you off course. So how does going 2 legs by the compass alone, and THEN the third leg towards the datum, account for currents, if EVERY object in the water (datum, PIW, boat) drifts more or less the same? Sure, it could correct for currents CHANGING direction in the search area, but it's not like currents twist that much to have the datum and the boat drifting in a completely different direction, and that's not what the coasties were saying. Can someone explain?

But if they're always returning to the floating datum that's being dragged by the current with the VS pattern, then doesn't that mean that whatever was in the water they're looking for will always be floating ahead of them and they never catch up?

20:00 - I'm no expert here... Buuuuut... How is this confusing looking path here along with all the extra work that comes with maintaining such a course superior to just doing a simple zig-zag style search pattern cutting back and forth at 45 degree angles over a straight center line that you'd plot to follow along in the direction of the current? In perfectly still water, sure this looks like a great way to fully search a circular area in the ocean by cutting it into triangular pie pieces, but as the wind/current increases to the level depicted here warping the search pattern this much it seems like a simple zig zag following a straight center line would accomplish the same coverage if not better coverage without having to waste extra time and fuel looping back in on yourself as shown here in this strange pattern...

Great video! Coming from Germany, it's interesting to see the coast guard beeing (pretty much) solely responsible for SAR missions. In Germany, the DGzRS, founded in 1865, is in charge of that. They are an independent organization working closely with the organs of the state, sporting 300 employees and 1500 volunteers at 55 stations, running 40 smaller SAR vessels and 20 cruisers (all enclosed, self righting, the cruisers also equiped with a tender), the flagship "Hermann Marwede" beeing the largest cruiser built solely for SAR missions worldwide to date, with a helipad and all the beels and whistles.
The coast guard will assist SAR missions on water if needed, while airborne SAR duties are carried out by the Bundeswehr and the Bundespolizei. For that reason, by comparison, our coast guard has a much more limited scope of tasks (basically it's only naval safety supervision, crime prevention and customs duties) and is rather small, sporting only 25 (larger) cruisers and tugs and a couple of helicopters. They will get assistance from the German Navy if need be of course.
That said, we have rather limited amounts of shore line, but some of the heaviest naval conditions on earth with the north see right at our doorstep, so its a very different situation compared to the US, and I totally understand why this concept wouldn't exactly work out in the US. So it's really fascinating to see the differences, yet also the similarities in day to day operation.
Interesting fact: those search patterns actually are the reason why we call our SAR ships "cruisers".

I am so happy that you are raising awareness of the U.S. Coast Guard.  I lived that life for four years, saving the lives of scores of people, None of whom I know personally. However, wearing Coast Guard swag, I have people thanking me for my service, which, serving just a few years after the end of the Vietnam War and remembering their cold reception returning home means alot. But what is really cool is that at least once a year, someone would come up to me and say that they are alive today because of the Coast Guard.  That's what it's all about. The Auxiliary taught people to be safer boaters and avoid becoming victims. Usually, the ones we rescued missed those classes. We also did law enforcement patrols to protect our shores and natural resources. Coast Guard ATON units, the black boats took care of all the aids to navigation and the red cutters are ice breakers. They love to back and ram. Or at least that's what their tee shirts claim. The helicopter swimmers are like the Coast Guard's special forces. After a hero with Navy Seals swimmers who rescue downed pilots assisted on a mission in the early 80s, rescuing victims too exhausted to get in a basket on their own,  the Coast Guard recognized that we needed the same resources, the Coast Guard AST's were born. Less than 50 percent of those who attend AST school actually make it through the training. They truly are a special bree d.

I took part in a (ultimately successful) search for two missing persons of a downed aircraft over the ocean, but the patterns proved entirely wrong in this case because they did not predict or include the possibility the persons in the water would be swimming towards the nearest shoreline, and had moved many miles from the search area.  I did happen to fly over the missing persons, as I was not part of the "official" search and/or pattern system, but I unfortunately did NOT see them in the water, and was only informed I flew over them by them telling me this after the fact.  (This is hard to hear and not get discouraged.)  As you mentioned, a person is VERY hard to see in the ocean unless you are very close to them.  When they were only a mile or so from the shoreline, they were ultimately spotted by an aircraft landing at a nearby airport.

The similarities between this search and rescue technique and a specific maneuver I learned in order to attain my commercial pilots certificate are almost a match. The maneuver is called “eights on pylon”. This maneuver is a ground reference maneuver where the speed over the ground determines your height above the object “pivotal altitude” where as you turn around the reference point, the object will stay under a specific area of the aircrafts wing. Just as drift comes into play in the search and rescue mission, the velocity of the wind will affect the ground speed of the aircraft. Instead of using the throttle to control the ground speed, the pilot will vary the altitude of the aircraft in order to stay at the pivotal altitude. We also enter the maneuver with the wind at our tail as the cost guard enters the grid with the drift behind them. The reason we start this maneuver with a tailwind is because the faster your ground speed, the higher the pivotal altitude. Being a “fixed power maneuver” it is preferable to descend and gain airspeed than to climb and lose airspeed. Starting pivotal altitude is determined by; (Ground Speed) squared / 11.3.

I have much respect for SAR crews whatever service they work for and for a deeply personal reason. My uncle was part of a five man RAF crew in 1955 flying a fixed wing search and rescue aircraft. This was before long-range helos and definitely before GPS. They responded to a call of a trawler in distress in the North Atlantic (somewhere between Ireland and Iceland). Their job was to locate the stricken ship and relay the coordinates to the nearest surface vessel. They did that, and were orbiting around the sinking trawler when something went horribly wrong and their plane went into the sea, killing all aboard. Fortunately they did their job long enough to enable the surface rescue vessel to arrive in time to save the fishermen. If only the technology we have now....

SAR work is dangerous by default, but I'm so glad that we now have tools that make saving the lives of those in distress easier and safer for the rescuers. And to my uncle James, you died before I was born, but know that when I stand silent every November 11, the tears I shed are for you.

If you want to get a complete story of the Coast Guard, you need to spend some time with the Coast Guard Auxiliary.  They are the volunteer, uniformed, civilian component of the Coast Guard.  The Auxiliary is referred to as America's Volunteer Life Savers.  We're open to any U.S. citizen who wishes to join.  We perform all of the missions of the Coast Guard except any law enforcement or combatant missions.  You join a local Flotilla, which is the operational unit in the Auxiliary.  Each flotilla operates under the supervision of their local Coast Guard station. The station's Commanding Officer (CO) is the Order Issuing Authority (OIA) for each flotilla within their Area of Responsibility (AOR).  One can join the Auxiliary at any time.  Feel free to contact me if you would like any further information.

A retired Coastie here.  It's good to see someone talking about what the Coast Guard does to help their fellow man in distress.  It's not talked about much, and I wish things like this was publicized more.  I think it would benefit the Coast Guard greatly.    I had a lot of fun in the Coast Guard, there's a lot of real good, and dedicated men and women hard at work 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, 365 days a year to do only one small part of the Coast Guard's job.   I don't regret the time I served, and I'd gladly do it again without hesitation.   I remember one SAR case I got involved in.  I was on a cutter returning from a Narcotics Patrol in the Caribbean, on our way home when we got tagged to do a SAR for a sailboat.  It was almost an all hands effort,  even I had  pair of binoculars and was looking for them.  I made a comment to one my fellow watchstanders saying "it's too bad we don't have a helo onboard".   I noticed the Captain jerked his head up and stared at me, then left the bridge.   The next morning we had a helo onboard.  After refueling it, giving the flight crew  bathroom break (called a head), and a snack, they were back in the air officially joining the SAR effort.   About 40 minutes into their patrol.  They found the sailboat.   All hands were rescued.   And we went home to loved ones we hadn't seen in almost 2 months.

Loved the aside on his experience with the concept of "datum".  The reality is that naval lingo includes datums through out the ships for alignments of sensors and weapons, let alone the propulsion shafts, etc.  The other nautical usage is a bit more mobid - the "flaming datum" is the symbol designated on the plot for a vessel damaged - likely by missiles or torpedoes, and around which vessels will respond (search and destroy threat, recover survivors).  The concept of a "datum" is certainly not exclusive to static situations.

A good way to visualize moving patterns like this is to rest your hand on something and draw the shape on a piece of paper next to it. Once you can do it without looking, do so while slowly pulling the paper. You still drew the pattern in exactly the same place relative to where you started (your hand stayed stationary), but the drift means that the reference point moved with the drift.

The Civil Air Patrol (US Air Force Auxiliary) uses the same SAR patterns as the USCG for CAP aerial searches, but instead of searching in moving water, the media that the aircraft moves in is air which moves also.  The difference of course is that usually the object of the SAR for the CAP is at a fixed point, so CAP uses GPS patterns and compensates for wind so that the area of the search is fully covered.  Very interesting to see how the CG does theirs when the media and the object of the search are moving together.  The search patterns used are the same, but the effect of the search is different when seen on a plot...  This is an awesome segment, Destin - thanks!

A trick my dad taught me when sailing or swimming at the beach is to wear a florescent orange shirt. If sailing, wear long pants. In the event you go overboard, and miss the drag line (rope you drag about 50 yards behind the sailboat to grab if you fall out), you take off your pants and make an improvised life vest. You can then maneuver your shirt off, and wave it over your head when you think the searchers are looking your way. It's not easy, but it makes finding you a lot easier. You can also drape the shirt over your head and improvised life vest to protect you from the sun while also increasing your visibility.

It feels like this relates to physics and navigation in space.
The actual GPS position of the Datum is irrelevant really, as it is moving relative to our perception of "standstill".
Much the same as the earth spinning on its axis, it's orbit round the sun and the solar systems movement in the galaxy all mean that we are never "Standstill". It is just our perception that we are not moving based on what we see around us.
Another example would be the Datum being on a conveyor belt and you try to walk the search pattern round it as it moves.

Magnesium sulfate is especially dangerous for pregnant women as it can cause serious birth defects to unborn fetuses. When I was in the Army, I learned a similar thing to the Victor Sierra for land navigation. We called it a Clover. Basically, if you're looking for something at a specific coordinate, you plot it out and get to wherever you think that coordinate is. Then you use wherever you are as a starting point and make four loops in every direction, like the leaves on a clover, to try to find what you're looking for.

Very cool, despite being a recreational sailor for 30+ years I learned something today :)  At one time in the sailing community, “man overboard poles” were standard equipment, basically a 2-3m long fiberglass pole with a weight at the bottom, float in the middle, and a flag on the top, commonly also attached to a life ring and buoyant line. The idea was to toss it over the side  if anyone ever went overboard.  The unit would act like the datum in this video, floating close to the person in the water as well as being a visual marker easy to see above the waves.   In recent years these poles have largely disappeared from boats in favor of GPS chart plotters where you can fix a waypoint if anyone goes overboard and the gps will bring you back to the waypoint. BUT the waypoint will be fixed in space and unlike the person in the water will not drift with the current and wind.  So the old fashioned MOB pole seems like a better tool to recover an overboard crew member  than the newfangled GPS method.

The other thing which we learn is that The Drift is the reason that Time Travel Is Impossible.
Case in point...
If you you very suddenly went back in time to the exact same place that you are now, 40 years into the past or future, you would wind up in the middle of outer space! Why? Because the Earth is always moving, and therefore your relative spot in the past or future is no longer on the Earth, because the Earth has drifted to a different location in space.
Make sense?

18:05 is NOT your fault, Destin. It's a terrible user interface convention that designers like me need to change. Power buttons should not be toggles. There should be separate "on" and "off" switches, which are idempotent (does the same thing no matter how many times you invoke them). It used to be standard that computers would forget all of your work until you hit "save". We finally changed that, and few people would want to go back. It's time to change the standard power button.

I retired from NOAA but before then created the AWOIS (Automated Wreck and Obstruction System). It stored all available information pertaining to the location of submerged wrecks and obstructions. The purpose was to aid in finding them in real time. Since NOAA was responsible for making charts of U.S. waters it was important that submerged hazards be accurately positioned. Difficult problem since often times the original sinking report was only very approximate. Knowing that a wreck would drift we used a CG program that calculated the most likely drift pattern over time. With that we knew better where to start a search pattern. Finding something floating is difficult, but once it sinks the problem becomes even more difficult. Thanks to the CG we were able to cut the time required to search and thereby reduce the cost. Government at work. Miss those days.

I learned to whistle using my fingers. I found that a thumb and index finger works best for me and allows me to do it one-handed. Depending on the situation I might go with pinkies or just the index fingers of I'm going to use both hands.

After learning that, I figured out that I can just sort of hold my tongue in the right space and shape to whistle with a very open mouth. Think about a big grin and that will give you the idea. It's open more side to side than up and down. The huge advantage is that it is less muted than a standard whistle because the mouth is more open. I then learned that I can move my lips around while doing this to effectively have "conversational whistling," where it looks like I might be talking, but you only hear whistling. In a larger group of people, I'll sort of blend in.

15-20 years later I learned the "standard" way. It just doesn't work as well. My open mouth style has the pitch control of the standard way, but it also has better control of the volume. Nothing is as loud as using fingers. Trying to get someone's attention or making noise in a crowd, it will cause discomfort to those within 10 feet of you. Ask me how I know.

We use these same search patterns in aviation searches for some of the same reasons.  We often have a last reported location, but because the aircraft we're looking for was usually still flying, we need to not only search that spot, but along the route it may have travelled.  So the sector gives us a quick and easy check on what the winds are doing in the local area and work off a known point for a chance at a quick acquisition.  If not, we may go to a route, expanding square, parallel, or creeping line.

A "VS" also allows searchers to view areas from different angles. Some things are easier to find when the Sun is beyond them. Some are easier to find when the Sun is behind the searcher. Sometimes things stand out better when the Sun is to one side or the other OR higher up in elevation or lower ... etc etc.
That Clover Leaf Pattern (my name for it) allows the searchers to view the same areas from different angles while also covering a fairly good size area in a short period of time.
The zig-zag stitched pattern is more useful when you have less idea where the Lost Victim might be OR when there are more variables (Day, Night, Sun High or Sun Low, Wind, Water Currents, Surface Currents, Tides or Rip-Tides, Large Object or Small, Bright Colors or dull etc etc).

They were smiling when you were talking about the “two different worlds” because sometimes the sectors plot the search pattern and  just send it to the boat crews without really looking at it.  It has been known for part of the search patterns to be over land or inaccessible areas when you plug it in to the GPS.  Normally the sectors catch it before they send it to the boat crews. However, there are times when the boat crews catch it because the sector didn’t.

I am so grateful that someone like Destin exists in this world. Not only is he extremely passionate about what he does, but he also legitimately enjoys showing and teaching people about all of the incredible and awesome things that he shows in his videos. He makes learning fun... He isn't afraid to admit when he doesn't know something or learns of a new way or method of doing something. He is so very humble and honest, and he genuinely gets a kick out of people learning something new, right along with him. I'm having a hard time finding the right words to describe what makes him, and this channel, so great... but I think that most people that watch his videos and are reading my comment likely know exactly what I'm trying to say here. He is far from being a try hard, unlike NDT and Bill Nye, who try to use big words and deflect when they are asked about something they don't know... He doesn't try to portray himself as both smarter than he is or that he is knowledgeable about anything and everything that someone might ask about.
In general, I just wanted to say thank you, Destin, for what you do... Showing that science and learning can be a load of fun, and teaching so many people about things that can absolutely become useful to them in the future. I personally believe that science teachers of all grades should take advantage of the wealth of information that exists in your library of videos, so that they can effectively teach kids in a way that keeps them captivated and helps then to retain the information that they've learned.

The floating datum is moving relative to the latitude/longitude grid. Meaning that it's moving relative to the land. However, the datum is in a fixed position relative to the moving water, biased by the force of the wind. In other words, the datum is fixed relative to where a human would be drifting.

Hi destin

I love that the RBM crew still has a completely analog method of calculating their heading and speed, and even has a basic rule of thumb calculation available. This must be such a relief to take their minds off the admin parts of searching, and focus on the actual looking part.
As someone from an IT background I can't tell you the number of times I have personally witnessed electronic devices fail to work at the exact moment that they were needed the most. So having an analog backup to computers and electronics is an incredible safety redundancy I love seeing, even in our modern times. Yes, they may not be as convenient or require certain basic skills to use, but they can be such a help when the electronics fail you in a certain way unforeseen by the software designers.
You really need to understand the basic principles behind these devices, not recieve an instruction manual and rote learning. Thank you, keep it up.
